title: Pouring Water — Pitcher to Pitcher
description: Introduction to the pouring exercise using two small pitchers. The child learns to transfer water carefully, developing concentration and motor control.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to the work area.
2. Show the child how to carry the tray with both hands.
3. Demonstrate pouring slowly from one pitcher to the other.
4. Allow the child to practice independently.
5. Show how to use the sponge to clean spills.
6. Return materials to the shelf when finished.

slides.heading: Pouring Water
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we are going to learn how to pour water, just like a big helper! We'll be using two special little jugs called pitchers to practice. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Place both pitchers on the tray. Fill one about halfway with water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our pouring adventure! We have two little pitchers, which are like tiny jugs for water, and a special tray to keep them on. We also have a soft sponge, just in case any water decides to go on a little trip! And of course, we need some water to pour! Ask a grown-up to help you get these things ready.

slides.text: Carry the tray carefully to the table with both hands.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend we're carrying something very special! We need to pick up our tray with both hands, like this, and walk super carefully to our table. We want to make sure our pitchers and water stay safe and sound on the tray.

slides.text: Pick up the full pitcher with your dominant hand. Place your other hand gently on the table for balance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pick up one of the pitchers. See how it has a handle? We'll hold that handle with our strong hand, and maybe put our other hand on the table to help us feel steady. This helps us be super strong and balanced!

slides.text: Slowly pour the water into the empty pitcher. Watch the water as it flows.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for the magic! We're going to hold the pitcher over the other one and tip it just a little bit. Watch the water flow out like a tiny, gentle stream. We want to be very slow and careful, like a little artist painting with water!

slides.text: Now pour it back! Try to pour slowly and steadily without spilling.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! Now, let's try pouring it back into the first pitcher. Remember to go slow and steady, like a little turtle. We are practicing being super careful with our pouring, and you are doing such a great job!

slides.prompt: Practice pouring back and forth 3 times. Can you do it without spilling?
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to practice pouring back and forth now! Let's try to pour the water from one pitcher to the other, and then back again, three times. Can you be a super pourer and try not to spill a single drop? You can do it!

slides.text: Use the sponge to clean up any spills. Dry the tray and return it to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour without spilling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Oops, did a little water jump out? That's okay! We have our special sponge to give the table a little bath and clean up any tiny spills. Then, we'll make sure our pitchers and tray are nice and dry and put them back where they belong. You were such a wonderful water pourer today!

parent_notes: This is often the first Practical Life exercise introduced. Let the child repeat as many times as they want — repetition builds concentration. Don't correct minor spills; the sponge is part of the self-correcting nature of the work. Use real glass pitchers (small size) rather than plastic, as the weight and breakability teach care and respect for materials.
household_substitutes: Two small pitchers or measuring cups
Baking sheet or tray to catch spills
preparation_steps: Fill one pitcher halfway with water. Place both on a tray. Have sponge and towel ready.
control_of_error: The child can see if water spilled on the tray. The sponge teaches self-correction.
extension_ideas: Try pouring colored water to see it better
Advance to pouring into smaller cups
Pour dry rice or beans for a quieter version

title: I Spy — Beginning Sounds (s)
description: Introduction to phonemic awareness through the classic Montessori 'I Spy' game focusing on the sound /s/.
instructions:
1. Gather 5-6 small objects that begin with the /s/ sound (sock, star, spoon, snake, stamp, stone).
2. Place objects on a tray or mat.
3. Say: 'I spy with my little eye something that begins with /s/.'
4. Let the child identify the object.
5. Repeat with each object.
6. Mix in 1-2 objects that don't start with /s/ as the child gains confidence.

slides.heading: I Spy
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun game we're going to play! It's called "I Spy," and we're going to be super detectives looking for special sounds. We'll be listening for the "sssss" sound that things make, just like a little snake!

items: 5-6 small objects starting with /s/ (sock, star, spoon, snake, stamp, stone)
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange objects neatly on the tray. Keep them visible and spaced apart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special things ready for our game! We need some cool objects like a soft sock, a shiny star, a yummy spoon, a slithery snake, a sticky stamp, and a smooth stone. We'll put them all on this tray so we can see them nice and close. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: Sit beside the child. Name each object clearly: 'This is a sock. This is a star. This is a spoon...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at our special things together. See this fluffy thing? It's a sock! And this twinkly thing is a star, and this shiny thing is a spoon. We're going to say their names and listen for the first sound they make.

slides.text: Say: 'I spy with my little eye something that begins with sssss.' Emphasize the /s/ sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, get your listening ears ready! I'm going to play a game, and I'll say, "I spy with my little eye something that begins with sssss." Can you listen for that "sssss" sound?

slides.text: When the child picks an object, say: 'Yes! Ssssock starts with /s/!' Emphasize the beginning sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you found it! That's right, that sock starts with our special "sssss" sound. You are so good at listening for the beginning sounds!

slides.prompt: Play I Spy with all the objects. Can you find everything that starts with /s/?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super spy! Let's find all the things on our tray that start with that "sssss" sound. Can you point to them or pick them up? You can do it!

slides.text: Extension: Ask the child to look around the room for other things that start with /s/.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's be treasure hunters! Can you look around our room and find other things that start with the "sssss" sound, like maybe your shoes or a special toy? It's like a scavenger hunt!

slides.text: Return objects to the basket. 'You found so many /s/ sounds today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify 4 out of 6 objects that start with /s/?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job playing "I Spy" today! You found so many things that start with the "sssss" sound, like the sock and the spoon! You are a super sound detective!

parent_notes: Always use the SOUND the letter makes, not the letter name. Say /s/ (like a snake hissing), not 'ess.' This is the foundation of Montessori reading instruction. Keep the game playful and pressure-free. If the child struggles, reduce to 3 objects. Collect small objects over time — dollar store miniatures work well.

title: Number Rods — Introduction (1-5)
description: Introduction to the Montessori number rods (rods 1-5). The child learns to associate quantity with the physical length of the rods.
instructions:
1. Bring the number rods (1-5) to the mat one at a time, starting with the shortest.
2. Build a stair pattern with the rods.
3. Count aloud as you touch each red-and-blue segment: 'One. One-two. One-two-three...'
4. Invite the child to count along with you.
5. Use the three-period lesson: 'This is one. This is two. Show me two. What is this?'
6. Allow the child to explore the rods freely.

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! These are called Number Rods, and today we're going to play with the first ones, from number one all the way up to number five. They help us learn about counting and how numbers can be different sizes!

items: Large floor mat or work rug
slides.setup_instructions: Place rods 1-5 in random order on the mat. Keep number cards nearby for later extension.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our counting game today! We have these colorful rods, and they are all different lengths. We also need a big mat to put them on, like a special floor for our toys. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find them all?

slides.text: Carry each rod to the mat one at a time, starting with the smallest. Hold with two hands.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our rods ready! We're going to pick them up one by one, starting with the shortest one. Hold them carefully with both hands so they don't wiggle away!

slides.text: Arrange the rods in a stair pattern from shortest (1) to longest (5), left-aligned.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to make a fun stair with our rods. We put the shortest one first, then the next shortest, and so on, until we have a big, beautiful staircase. It's like building a rainbow with our hands!

slides.text: Touch the first rod and say 'One.' Touch each segment of the second rod: 'One, two.' Continue through rod 5.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count our special rods together! We'll touch the first rod and say "One." Then we touch the next rod and count "One, two." We keep going all the way to the end, counting each little colored part.

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is three' (naming). 'Show me three' (recognition). 'What is this?' (recall).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll play a counting game! I'll show you a rod and tell you its number, like "This is three." Then I'll ask you to find the rod that has three parts, and then you can tell me what number it is. It's like a fun guessing game!

slides.prompt: Build the stair! Can you put the rods in order from 1 to 5?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to build our stair all by ourselves! Can you put the rods in order from the shortest one to the longest one? You're going to make a perfect number staircase, just like a super builder!

slides.text: Carry each rod back to the shelf one at a time. 'You counted all the way to five!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the stair and count to 5 with the rods?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You built the number stair and counted all the way to five! You were so good at putting them in order, just like a super mathematician!

parent_notes: Number rods give a concrete, physical experience of quantity. Rod 3 is literally three times longer than rod 1. Always count from left to right, touching each segment. If your child doesn't have official number rods, you can make them with dowels painted in alternating red and blue segments (each segment = 10cm).

title: Land and Water — Introduction
description: Introduction to land and water forms using a globe and a simple tray demonstration. The child learns that Earth is made of land and water.
instructions:
1. Show the child the Montessori globe (sandpaper globe or colored globe).
2. Let the child feel the rough (land) and smooth (water) surfaces.
3. Explain: 'The blue parts are water. The rough/brown parts are land.'
4. Pour water into one side of a land/water tray to demonstrate.
5. Let the child explore pouring water around the land form.
6. Discuss: 'What do we see more of — land or water?'

slides.heading: Land and Water
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big picture! It says "Land and Water." That means we're going to learn about the special parts of our home, the Earth. Isn't that exciting?

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe on the table. Have the land/water tray nearby with an empty pitcher and a pitcher of water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our adventure! We have a big ball that looks like our Earth, a special tray, a little pitcher for water, and even a sponge to clean up. Can you help your grown-up find all these things to play with?

slides.text: Hold the globe and say: 'This is our Earth. It is where we all live.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This big ball is our Earth, the whole world where we live! It's like a giant playground for everyone. Let's pretend we're going to touch our Earth.

slides.text: Guide the child's hand over the globe: 'Feel the rough parts — that is land. Feel the smooth parts — that is water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's use our hands to feel the Earth. Feel this part – it feels bumpy and rough, like sand! That's the land where we walk and play. Now feel this part – it's super smooth and cool. That's the water, like in the big ocean!

slides.text: Ask: 'Is there more land or more water on Earth?' (Water!) 'That's right — most of Earth is covered in water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to look at our Earth again and guess something important. Do you think there's more land, or more water on our Earth? (Pause for answer) That's right, there's way more water! The blue water covers almost all of our home.

slides.prompt: Pour water into the land/water tray. Watch how the water fills in around the land. Where does the water go?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We get to pour water into our special tray. Watch how the water finds its way around the land, just like it does on the real Earth. Can you see where the water likes to go?

slides.text: Use the sponge to clean up. 'Today we learned that Earth has land and water!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify land and water on the globe?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We learned that our Earth has bumpy land and smooth water, and that there's a lot more water than land. You were so good at exploring and pouring!

parent_notes: If you don't have a Montessori sandpaper globe, use any globe and have the child notice the blue (water) and green/brown (land) colors. For the land/water tray, you can use a simple baking dish with clay molded into a land form on one side. This lesson plants the seed for all future geography work.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Read-Aloud: Goodnight Moon
description: Shared reading of the classic picture book 'Goodnight Moon' by Margaret Wise Brown, with discussion about nighttime routines and rhyming words.
instructions:
1. Show the cover and read the title. Ask: 'What do you see on the cover?'
2. Read the story slowly, pointing to the pictures.
3. Pause to let the child notice details in the illustrations.
4. After reading, discuss: 'What things did the bunny say goodnight to?'
5. Ask: 'What do you say goodnight to in your room?'
6. Re-read, pausing before rhyming words to let the child fill them in.
materials_needed: Goodnight Moon by Margaret Wise Brown
Optional: small blanket or stuffed animal

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Goodnight Moon by Margaret Wise Brown
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! This is the cover of a book we're going to read together. It's called "Goodnight Moon," and it's about getting ready for bed. What fun things do you see on the cover?

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together in a comfortable spot. Hold the book so the child can see the pictures clearly.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need just two things for our special reading time! First, we need this book, "Goodnight Moon." Second, we need a super cozy spot, like a comfy chair or a soft rug, where we can snuggle up.

slides.text: Show the cover: 'This book is called Goodnight Moon. What do you see on the cover?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look at the very front of the book! This is called the cover. The book's name is "Goodnight Moon." What do you see on the cover? Tell me all about it!

slides.text: Read slowly. Point to the illustrations. Let the child look at each page before turning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story together, nice and slow. I'll point to the pictures as we go. Take your time to look at all the fun things in each picture before we turn the page.

slides.text: Pause on rhyming pages: 'Goodnight kittens, goodnight ___' and let the child guess 'mittens!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we get to some special parts, I'll stop and we can guess the rhyming word together. For example, I might say "Goodnight mittens," and you can help me say the rhyming word, like "kittens!"

slides.prompt: After reading: 'What things in YOUR room would you say goodnight to?' Let the child name items.
slides.mascot_explanation: After we read the story, we'll talk about our own rooms! What special things in your room do you like to say goodnight to before you go to sleep? Maybe your teddy bear or your favorite blanket?

slides.text: Re-read the story if the child wants to hear it again. Repetition is wonderful at this age!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recall 3-4 items from the story?
slides.mascot_explanation: We can read the story again if you want, because reading the same book lots of times is super good for learning! Did you have fun finding all the things the bunny said goodnight to?

parent_notes: Read-alouds are the single most important activity for developing literacy. Read with expression and warmth. Don't rush. If your child wants to hear it again, read it again! Repetition builds vocabulary and comprehension. Point out rhyming words naturally — this builds phonological awareness, a key pre-reading skill.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Pink Tower — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Pink Tower. The child builds the tower from largest to smallest cube, developing visual discrimination of size.
instructions:
1. Carry each cube individually to the mat, starting with the largest.
2. Scatter the cubes randomly on the mat.
3. Find the largest cube and place it in the center.
4. Find the next largest and center it on top.
5. Continue stacking from largest to smallest.
6. Admire the completed tower, then carefully disassemble.

slides.heading: The Pink Tower
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about the Pink Tower today. It's a special building toy that helps us see how things can be big and small. We'll learn how to build it from the biggest piece all the way to the smallest piece.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the mat on the floor. Carry each cube one at a time from the shelf to the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the pink blocks! These are the special blocks for our Pink Tower. We also have a big soft mat for us to build on. First, we need to carefully carry each pink block, one by one, to the mat. Can you help find them?

slides.text: Carry the largest cube with two hands. Place it on the mat. Go back for the next cube.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start building! We need to pick up the very biggest pink block with both hands. Hold it nice and steady, and then we'll put it down right in the middle of our mat. Great job! Now, let's go get the next block.

slides.text: When all 10 cubes are on the mat, scatter them gently. 'Now let's build the tower!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have all our pink blocks on the mat now! Let's gently spread them out a little bit so we can see them all. Now it's time for the super fun part: we get to build our tower!

slides.text: Pick up the largest cube. Place it in the center of the mat. 'This is our base — the biggest cube.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We need to find the biggest, fattest pink block again. We already put it down in the middle, and that's our strong bottom for the tower. It's like the base of a house, making sure everything else can stand up tall.

slides.text: Find the next biggest. Center it carefully on top. Continue until all 10 cubes are stacked.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's find the block that's just a little bit smaller than the one we already have. We'll carefully put it right on top of the biggest one, making sure it's in the middle. We'll keep doing this, finding the next smallest block each time, until our tower is all finished!

slides.prompt: Now it's your turn! Can you build the Pink Tower from biggest to smallest?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's your turn to build the Pink Tower all by yourself! Can you find the biggest block and put it down first? Then find the next biggest and stack it right on top. Keep going until all the blocks are in a tall tower, from biggest to smallest. You can do it!

slides.text: Carefully take the tower apart. Carry each cube back to the shelf one at a time.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the tower in the correct order without help?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job building the Pink Tower! Now, let's carefully take it apart, block by block, starting with the smallest one on top. We'll carry each one back to where it belongs, just like we did when we started. You were so good at building it from biggest to smallest!

parent_notes: The Pink Tower is one of the most iconic Montessori materials. It isolates the concept of SIZE — each cube differs by exactly 1 cm in each dimension. The child's eyes learn to discriminate differences in three dimensions. Don't correct errors verbally; the tower itself shows the child if a cube is out of place. If you don't have a Pink Tower, you can use graduated nesting blocks.

title: Sandpaper Letter — s
description: Introduction to the sandpaper letter 's'. The child traces the letter while hearing its sound, building a multi-sensory connection between symbol and sound.
instructions:
1. Place the sandpaper letter 's' on the table.
2. Trace the letter with your index and middle fingers while saying '/s/' (the sound, not the name).
3. Repeat three times.
4. Invite the child to trace while you say the sound together.
5. Three-period lesson: 'This is /s/.' 'Show me /s/.' 'What sound is this?'
6. Connect to I Spy: 'Remember the objects that start with /s/?'

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun picture! It shows us a special letter that makes a sound we're going to learn today. We're going to have so much fun exploring it together!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the sandpaper letter on the tray. If using a sand tray, have it nearby for extension work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our letter adventure! We have a special bumpy letter 's' and a little tray to put it on. We also have a tray with sand, which is like magic drawing paper for letters!

slides.text: Sit beside the child. Place the sandpaper letter between you. 'Today we're going to learn a new sound.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready to learn! We're going to sit together right here, and we'll put our special bumpy letter 's' right between us. Today is all about learning a brand new sound!

slides.text: Trace the letter slowly with your index and middle fingers. Say '/s/' as you trace. Repeat 3 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's use our fingers to feel the bumpy letter 's'. We're going to trace it slowly, like we're drawing a wiggly snake, and say its sound: /s/. We'll do this three times to make sure we remember!

slides.text: Guide the child's fingers over the letter: 'Now you try. Feel the letter and say /s/.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to be the letter explorer! I'll help your fingers feel the bumpy 's' and we can say the sound /s/ together. Feel how it feels and make the sound with me!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This says /s/' → 'Show me /s/' → 'What sound does this make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we play a little game! I'll tell you 'This says /s/', then I'll ask you to 'Show me /s/', and finally, you tell me, "What sound does this make?" It's like a fun guessing game!

slides.prompt: Practice tracing the letter 5 times. Then try writing /s/ in the sand tray!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice tracing our bumpy 's' five times, and then we can pretend to write it in the sand! It's like drawing in the sand to make the /s/ sound. You're going to be so good at this!

slides.text: Return the sandpaper letter to the shelf. 'You learned the sound /s/ today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the letter and say the correct sound?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a super job learning the /s/ sound today! We traced the bumpy letter and made the sound together. You are a fantastic learner, and I'm so proud of you!

parent_notes: Sandpaper letters are the cornerstone of Montessori reading instruction. The child learns through THREE senses simultaneously: seeing the shape, feeling the texture, and hearing the sound. Always use lowercase letters first. Always teach the SOUND (/s/ like a snake), never the letter name ('ess'). If you don't have sandpaper letters, make them by cutting letters from fine sandpaper and gluing to cardstock.

title: Number Rods — Counting Practice (1-5)
description: Continued work with number rods 1-5. The child practices counting each rod's segments and ordering the rods by length.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to bring the number rods (1-5) to the mat.
2. Mix the rods randomly.
3. Ask the child to find rod 1. Then rod 2. Continue through 5.
4. Build the stair together.
5. Count each rod's segments aloud.
6. Play 'Show me': 'Show me the rod that has 3.' 'Which rod has 5?'

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Hello friend! Today we're going to play with special blocks called number rods. We'll learn how to count them, all the way up to five! It's going to be super fun.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the child carry rods to the mat. Mix them up randomly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these colorful blocks! These are our number rods, and we need them to practice counting. See this nice big space on the floor? That's our mat where we'll play. Can you help me carry all the rods to the mat? Let's mix them up so it's a surprise!

slides.text: 'Can you find the rod that shows ONE?' Wait for the child to find it. Place it at the top.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you found the first rod! This tiny one is rod number one. We're going to start building a special staircase with our rods, and this one goes right at the very top.

slides.text: 'Now find TWO.' Continue through five. Build the stair as each rod is found.
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job finding rod number two! Now we'll put it right under the first one. We'll keep finding the next number rod, and then put them in order to make a cool stair shape.

slides.text: Count each rod together, touching each segment: 'One. One-two. One-two-three...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count the little bumps on each rod together! We'll touch each one as we say the number. We'll count them all the way up, just like climbing stairs!

slides.prompt: Play 'Show Me': 'Show me three!' 'Show me five!' 'Which rod has four?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for a game! I'll say a number, and you show me the rod that has that many bumps. Can you show me the rod with three? You're doing such a great job counting!

slides.text: Return rods to the shelf. 'Great counting today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and count rods 1-5 independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did amazing counting all the number rods today! We learned how to find them and count them all by ourselves. You can put them back now, and we can play again soon!

parent_notes: Repetition is key. The child may want to build the stair many times — encourage this! You can extend by asking comparison questions: 'Which is longer, 3 or 5?' 'How many more does 5 have than 3?' Don't push the extensions; let the child's interest guide the work.

title: Nature Walk — Observing Our World
description: A guided nature walk to observe the natural world, collect specimens, and practice careful observation — a foundation for scientific thinking.
instructions:
1. Prepare a nature walk basket (bag, magnifying glass, collection containers).
2. Walk slowly through a garden, park, or yard.
3. Stop frequently: 'What do you notice? What do you see, hear, smell?'
4. Collect 3-5 natural items (leaves, rocks, flowers, sticks).
5. Return home and examine collections with the magnifying glass.
6. Sort items: living vs. non-living, or by color/texture.

slides.heading: Nature Walk
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! Today we get to go on a special adventure outside called a nature walk. We're going to look all around and see all the amazing things in our world!

slides.setup_instructions: Pack the basket. Dress for the weather. Choose a safe walking area.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our walk, we need a few special things. We need a basket to carry our treasures, a special glass to look at things up close, and some little boxes or bags to keep our finds safe. Can you ask a grown-up to help you get these ready?

slides.text: 'Today we are going on a nature walk! We are going to use our eyes, ears, and noses to observe the world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, we're starting our adventure! We're going to use our super eyes to see everything, our listening ears to hear all the sounds, and maybe even our noses to smell the flowers!

slides.text: Walk slowly. Stop often: 'Look at this leaf! What color is it? What shape? Feel the edges.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we walk super slow, like little explorers! When we see something interesting, we stop and look very, very closely. We can see what color it is or how it feels.

slides.text: Collect 3-5 items. 'Let's put this interesting rock in our basket to look at later.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find some special things to take home! We can pick up a pretty leaf, a smooth stone, or a cool stick. We want to find about three to five treasures to put in our basket.

slides.prompt: Back inside: examine your finds with the magnifying glass. Sort them into groups. What groups did you make?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're back inside! Now we get to use our magnifying glass to look at all the cool things we found, like tiny bugs on a leaf! Then, we can put them into groups, like all the green things together or all the bumpy things together.

slides.text: Display your favorite find on the nature shelf. 'What was the most interesting thing you found?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 2-3 observations about an item they found?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! Let's pick your very favorite thing you found and put it somewhere special. What was the most exciting thing you saw on our nature walk today?

parent_notes: Nature walks are a cornerstone of Montessori education. The goal is not to cover distance but to observe deeply. Walk slowly. Let the child lead. A magnifying glass transforms any leaf or rock into a wonder. Start a nature shelf at home where the child can display their finds — this connects to the Montessori love of order and classification.
preparation_steps: Choose a safe outdoor area. Bring observation tools and journal.
control_of_error: Compare observations with field guides or look up findings together.
extension_ideas: Press leaves or flowers
Start a nature collection
Photograph interesting finds

title: Free Drawing — Exploring Crayons
description: Free exploration of drawing materials. The child experiments with crayons, learning grip, pressure, and the joy of making marks on paper.
instructions:
1. Set up a drawing workspace: large paper, crayons, and a placemat.
2. Show the child the proper tripod grip for holding a crayon.
3. Demonstrate making different kinds of lines: straight, curvy, zigzag, circles.
4. Invite the child to draw freely — no specific product expected.
5. Talk about what the child is making: 'Tell me about your drawing.'
6. Display the finished work.
materials_needed: Placemat or newspaper to protect table

slides.heading: Free Drawing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! This is our special art time where we get to play with crayons and make beautiful pictures. We're going to have so much fun exploring all the colors!

slides.setup_instructions: Set out paper and crayons. Keep the workspace uncluttered. Let the child choose colors.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our drawing adventure, we need a few things! See this big paper? That's where all our amazing art will go. And look at all these colorful crayons – they're like magic sticks that make pictures appear! We also have a special mat to keep our table nice and clean while we draw. Can you help mommy or daddy find these things?

slides.text: Show the tripod grip: 'Hold the crayon like this — thumb, pointer finger, and middle finger.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's learn how to hold our crayon so we can make the best drawings! See how my thumb, my pointer finger, and my middle finger are all holding the crayon? This is called a tripod grip, and it helps us make super cool lines. Try holding it just like this!

slides.text: Make different lines: 'Watch — I can make a straight line, a curvy line, a zigzag, and a circle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now watch me, I can make all sorts of fun marks with my crayon! I can make a straight line that goes up and down, a wiggly line that goes side to side, and even a big circle! It's like dancing on the paper with my crayon.

slides.text: 'Now it's your turn! Draw whatever you like. There is no right or wrong way.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn now to be the artist! You can draw anything you want on the paper. There's no wrong way to draw, so just have fun and let your imagination run wild! What will you create today?

slides.prompt: Draw freely for 10-15 minutes. Try making different kinds of lines and shapes!
slides.mascot_explanation: We have lots of time to draw, draw, draw! You can make straight lines, curvy lines, circles, and anything else you can think of. Just keep drawing and exploring all the cool things your crayons can do!

slides.text: Ask: 'Tell me about your drawing.' Write their words on the back. Display it proudly!
slides.mastery_check: Is the child using a functional grip and exploring different mark types?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your amazing artwork! Tell me all about it – what did you draw? We'll write your wonderful story on the back and hang it up so everyone can see your masterpiece. You did such a fantastic job exploring and creating!

parent_notes: Process over product! At this age, the goal is exploration and fine motor development, not recognizable pictures. Never say 'What is it?' Instead say 'Tell me about your drawing.' Chunky crayons are easier for younger children; regular crayons work for older kindergartners with developed grips. Save early drawings to compare with later ones — the growth will amaze you.
household_substitutes: Cup of water and paper towels
preparation_steps: Cover the work surface. Set out materials in order of use. Demonstrate technique first.
control_of_error: Art is self-expressive — focus on the process, not the product.
extension_ideas: Display the artwork proudly
Try the same subject with a different medium
Look at famous artwork for inspiration

title: Pouring Dry Goods — Rice Transfer
description: Pouring exercise using dry rice. The child transfers rice from one container to another, refining motor control and listening skills.
instructions:
1. Place two small bowls and a cup of dry rice on a tray.
2. Demonstrate slowly pouring rice from one bowl to the other.
3. Listen to the sound the rice makes.
4. Let the child practice pouring back and forth.
5. Show how to pick up any spilled grains.
6. Return materials to the shelf.

slides.heading: Pouring Dry Goods
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special lesson today. We are going to have so much fun pouring!

slides.setup_instructions: Fill one bowl about halfway with rice. Place both bowls on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we get to use! We have two little bowls, yummy rice that feels so neat, and a tray to keep everything tidy. We also have a tiny broom and pan for any little oopsies! Ask your grown-up to help you get them ready.

slides.text: Carry the tray to the table. 'Today we are going to pour rice!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's carry our tray very carefully to our table. Today, we get to play with rice and practice pouring!

slides.text: Pick up the full bowl carefully with both hands. Pour the rice slowly into the empty bowl.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, pick up the bowl with the rice with both of your hands, like you're giving it a big hug. Slowly, tip it just a little bit, and watch the rice tumble into the other bowl.

slides.text: 'Listen to the sound! What does the rice sound like?' Pour it back.
slides.mascot_explanation: Shhh, listen closely! Can you hear the rice making a soft sound as it falls? Let's pour it back and listen again!

slides.prompt: Practice pouring the rice back and forth 5 times. Try not to spill any grains!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the pouring star! Let's pour the rice back and forth, five times, trying to keep all the little grains inside the bowls. You can do it!

slides.text: Use the hand broom to sweep up any spilled rice. Return the tray to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour dry goods with minimal spilling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did such a great job pouring! If any rice spilled, let's use our little broom and pan to clean it all up, just like a helper. Then, we'll put our tray back so it's ready for next time!

parent_notes: Dry pouring is typically introduced before or alongside water pouring. Rice provides auditory feedback — the child can hear when grains spill. The clean-up process (sweeping spilled rice) is an integral part of the work, not a punishment. You can vary the dry goods: rice, lentils, beans, or pasta provide different weights and sounds.
preparation_steps: Fill one bowl with rice/beans. Place both on the tray.
control_of_error: Spilled grains on the tray show where control is needed. Child sweeps up any spills.
extension_ideas: Use different sized containers
Try with a funnel
Count how many spoonfuls fill a cup

title: I Spy — Beginning Sounds (m)
description: I Spy game focusing on the sound /m/. The child identifies objects beginning with /m/ to develop phonemic awareness.
instructions:
1. Gather objects: mitten, marble, mushroom (toy), mouse (toy), mug, map.
2. Name each object clearly.
3. Play I Spy: 'I spy something that starts with /m/.'
4. After mastery, mix /s/ and /m/ objects together.
5. 'I spy something that starts with /s/.' Then switch to /m/.
6. Celebrate the child's growing sound awareness.

slides.heading: I Spy
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun game we're going to play! It's called "I Spy," and we'll be listening for a special sound, the "mmm" sound. It's like a secret code we'll learn to hear!

items: 5-6 objects starting with /m/ (mitten, marble, mushroom, mouse, mug, map)
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange the /m/ objects on the tray. Keep /s/ objects in a separate basket for the extension.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these cool things! We have a cozy mitten, a little marble, a toy mushroom, a tiny mouse, a mug for pretend drinks, and a map. These are all the special treasures we need to start our sound game!

slides.text: Name each object: 'This is a mitten. This is a marble. This is a mushroom...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at each thing together. This is a soft mitten, and this is a round marble, and this is a funny mushroom toy, and so on. We're just saying their names so we know them really well!

slides.text: 'I spy something that starts with mmm.' Emphasize the /m/ sound (humming).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time for the "I Spy" game! I'm going to whisper a secret sound, "mmm," and you have to find something that starts with that sound. Can you make the "mmm" sound with me?

slides.text: When comfortable, add the /s/ objects. Now the child must listen carefully to distinguish /s/ from /m/.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, we might hear other sounds too, like "sss." So, we need to listen super carefully to know if it's the "mmm" sound or the "sss" sound. It's like being a super sound detective!

slides.prompt: Sort the objects into two groups: /s/ objects and /m/ objects!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now comes the super fun part! Let's put all the treasures in two piles: one for things that start with "mmm" and one for things that start with "sss." You get to decide where each one goes!

slides.text: Return everything to the baskets. 'You know two sounds now — /s/ and /m/!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish /s/ and /m/ beginning sounds?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned to hear both the "mmm" sound and the "sss" sound. You are such a smart listener, and you're going to be amazing at finding sounds everywhere!

parent_notes: We introduce /m/ early because it's a continuous sound (you can stretch it: 'mmmm') and it's common in early words (mom, me, my). When mixing two sounds, you're building the child's ability to discriminate — a critical reading skill. Don't rush to add more sounds; mastery of 2-3 is better than exposure to 10.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 1, 2, 3
description: Introduction to sandpaper numerals 1, 2, and 3. The child traces each numeral while saying the number name, building a tactile connection to written numerals.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper numeral 1. Trace with two fingers while saying 'one.'
2. Present numeral 2. Trace while saying 'two.'
3. Present numeral 3. Trace while saying 'three.'
4. Three-period lesson for each: naming, recognition, recall.
5. Match sandpaper numerals to number rods.
6. Let the child practice tracing independently.

slides.heading: Sandpaper Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to learn about some special numbers: one, two, and three! They have a bumpy feeling that will help us remember them.

slides.setup_instructions: Place sandpaper numerals face-down on the tray. Have number rods nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few things for our number fun! We have special bumpy numbers, like this one that feels like a '1'. We also have some sticks that show us how many, like a stick for '1', a stick for '2', and a stick for '3'. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready on a tray.

slides.text: Turn over numeral 1. Trace it with two fingers, top to bottom. Say 'one.' Repeat 3 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start with our first bumpy number! We flip it over, and it's the number one! Let's trace it with our fingers, like we're drawing it in the air, and say "one" together. We'll do it three times to really feel it!

slides.text: Turn over numeral 2. Trace while saying 'two.' Then numeral 3: trace and say 'three.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job with number one! Now let's do the same for the number two, tracing it and saying "two" with our fingers. Then we'll do it for the number three, tracing and saying "three."

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is one.' 'Show me two.' 'What number is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to play a little game to remember our numbers. I'll say "This is one," and then I'll ask you to "Show me two." Then, I'll point to a number and ask, "What number is this?" It's like a fun guessing game!

slides.text: Match: Place numeral 1 next to rod 1. 'This symbol means one, and this rod shows one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's see if we can match our bumpy numbers to our sticks. We'll put the bumpy '1' next to the stick that has just one part, because they both mean 'one'! It's like they're best friends.

slides.prompt: Match all three numerals to their rods. Then trace each numeral 3 more times.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for our special number-matching game! Can you find the bumpy '2' and put it next to the stick that shows two? Then find the bumpy '3' and match it to the stick with three parts! After that, let's trace each bumpy number one more time, just for fun.

slides.text: Return materials to the shelf. 'You can write 1, 2, and 3!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and name numerals 1, 2, and 3?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job learning our numbers today! You can trace and say one, two, and three all by yourself now! Let's put our special bumpy numbers and sticks back where they belong.

parent_notes: Sandpaper numerals work the same way as sandpaper letters — the child learns through touch, sight, and sound simultaneously. Always trace in the correct formation direction. Match numerals to rods to connect the abstract symbol with the concrete quantity. You can make DIY sandpaper numerals by cutting numbers from sandpaper and gluing to cardboard.

title: The Globe — Continents Introduction
description: Introduction to the continents using the Montessori colored globe. The child learns the names of the seven continents through a multi-sensory presentation.
instructions:
1. Present the colored globe.
2. Point to each continent and say its name slowly.
3. Focus on 2-3 continents today: North America, South America, Africa.
4. Sing a continent song if desired.
5. Ask: 'We live on this continent — North America!'
6. Let the child spin the globe and point to continents they remember.

slides.heading: The Globe
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun picture! It's called "The Globe" and it's like a big ball that shows us our whole world. We're going to learn about some special big pieces of land on it today!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe on the table at the child's eye level.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at this special ball! This is our globe, and it has different colors for different parts of the world. Sometimes grown-ups put little names on it, but we don't need those right now. We just need this super cool globe!

slides.text: Spin the globe gently. 'This is our whole world! There are seven big pieces of land called continents.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's give our globe a gentle spin, just like this! Boop! See how it turns? This big ball shows us our whole world, and there are seven giant pieces of land called continents. We're going to learn about them!

slides.text: Point to North America (orange): 'This is North America. We live here!' Let the child touch it.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this orange part? This is called North America, and guess what? We live here! Can you touch it? It's where our homes are.

slides.text: Point to South America (pink): 'This is South America. It's connected to North America.' Point to Africa (green): 'This is Africa. It's very big!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look, this pink part is South America, and it's right next to North America, like best friends holding hands. And this big green part is Africa! It's a really, really big place.

slides.prompt: 'Can you find North America? Where is Africa?' Let the child point to the continents on the globe.
slides.mascot_explanation: Can you find the orange one, North America, on our globe? You're so good at this! Now, can you point to the big green one, Africa? Yay, you found them!

slides.text: 'Today we learned three continents: North America, South America, and Africa. Next time we'll meet more!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child point to and name at least 2 of the 3 continents introduced?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned so many new things today! We met North America, South America, and Africa. You did such a great job finding them on the globe. Next time, we'll meet even more continents!

parent_notes: Montessori introduces geography early and concretely — children are naturally fascinated by the whole world. Each continent has a traditional Montessori color (North America = orange, South America = pink, Europe = red, Asia = yellow, Africa = green, Australia = brown, Antarctica = white). Don't expect mastery of all seven at once; we'll review throughout the year.

title: Nursery Rhymes — Jack and Jill & Humpty Dumpty
description: Learning classic nursery rhymes through recitation, rhythm, and movement. Nursery rhymes build phonological awareness and memory.
instructions:
1. Recite 'Jack and Jill' slowly. Use hand motions.
2. Repeat line by line, having the child echo.
3. Recite together 2-3 times.
4. Move to 'Humpty Dumpty.' Recite with dramatic expression.
5. Let the child act it out: sit on a 'wall' (chair), pretend to fall.
6. Recite both rhymes together at the end.
materials_needed: Props: small pail for Jack and Jill, egg for Humpty Dumpty (optional)

slides.heading: Nursery Rhymes
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the title! We're going to learn some super fun songs called nursery rhymes, like "Jack and Jill" and "Humpty Dumpty." These are old, old songs that lots of kids love to sing!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together in a comfortable spot. Face the child so they can see your mouth and expressions.
slides.mascot_explanation: These are some fun things we can use to help us learn our rhymes! If you have a book with pictures, we can look at it together. And we have a little pail and a pretend egg – maybe we can pretend to be Jack and Jill or Humpty Dumpty!

slides.text: Recite 'Jack and Jill went up the hill...' slowly. Use hand motions: walking fingers up, tumbling down.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to sing "Jack and Jill"! Let's say the words really slowly together. We can even pretend our fingers are walking up a hill, and then tumbling down!

slides.text: Repeat line by line. You say a line, the child echoes it. Then say the whole rhyme together.
slides.mascot_explanation: This time, I'll say a little bit of the rhyme, and you can sing it back to me, like an echo! Then, we'll sing the whole thing together, just you and me.

slides.text: Now 'Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall...' Use dramatic expressions — gasp when he falls!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for "Humpty Dumpty"! We're going to make our voices sound extra excited, and maybe even gasp when he falls down! It's going to be so much fun!

slides.prompt: Act out Humpty Dumpty! Sit on a chair (the wall), then slide off gently (the fall). Can you put Humpty together again?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend to be Humpty Dumpty! You can sit on this chair, like it's a wall, and then gently slide down like he did. Can you help put Humpty back together after he falls?

slides.text: Recite both rhymes together one more time. 'You learned two rhymes today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite most of at least one rhyme independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We learned two whole rhymes today, "Jack and Jill" and "Humpty Dumpty"! You were so great at singing and acting them out, especially when we pretended Humpty fell off the wall!

parent_notes: Nursery rhymes are language gold. They build phonological awareness (hearing rhyme and rhythm), vocabulary, and memory. Research shows children who know nursery rhymes become better readers. Don't worry about perfect recitation — the rhythm and rhyme are what matter. Add hand motions and acting to make them memorable and fun.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Transferring with Tongs
description: The child uses tongs to transfer objects between bowls, strengthening the hand muscles needed for writing and developing concentration.
instructions:
1. Place two bowls on a tray — one filled with cotton balls (or pom-poms), one empty.
2. Demonstrate picking up one object with the tongs.
3. Transfer it to the empty bowl.
4. Show the child the proper grip on the tongs.
5. Let the child transfer all objects.
6. When finished, transfer them back.

slides.heading: Transferring
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! Today we're going to play a fun game called "Transferring." It means we'll move little things from one place to another, like magic!

slides.setup_instructions: Place cotton balls in one bowl. Set both bowls and tongs on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need for our game! We have two little bowls, some soft and fluffy cotton balls, and these cool grabby tools called tongs. We'll use the tray to keep everything tidy while we play.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to use tongs to move these cotton balls.' Show the tongs.
slides.mascot_explanation: See these grabby tools? They're called tongs, and today we're going to use them to move these fluffy cotton balls. They help us practice using our hands, which is super important for when we draw and write!

slides.text: Demonstrate: squeeze the tongs to open, grab one cotton ball, carry it over, release into the empty bowl.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! First, I squeeze the tongs to open them up wide, then I grab just one fluffy cotton ball. Now I carry it over to the empty bowl and let go! See?

slides.text: 'Your turn! Squeeze, pick up, carry, and release. One at a time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! Squeeze the tongs to grab a cotton ball, then carry it over and let it go in the other bowl. Remember, just one fluffy ball at a time, nice and slow. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Transfer all the cotton balls. Then transfer them back! How fast can you do it carefully?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's move all the fluffy cotton balls from one bowl to the other using our tongs. When we're all done, we'll move them all back again! Try to be super careful and gentle.

slides.text: Return the tray to the shelf. 'Your hands are getting stronger!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child successfully transfer objects using tongs?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You moved all the cotton balls with the tongs, and your hands are getting so much stronger, just like a superhero! Putting the tray away neatly is the perfect ending to our game.

parent_notes: Tong work is brilliant for developing the pincer grip and hand strength needed for writing. Start with large, light objects (cotton balls) and gradually move to smaller items (beads, beans). Kitchen tongs, strawberry hullers, or tweezers all work. This is a wonderful independent activity once demonstrated — put it on a shelf for the child to choose freely.
household_substitutes: Cotton balls, pom-poms, or large beads
preparation_steps: Place items in one bowl. Set tongs and both bowls on tray.
control_of_error: Dropped items show where the child needs more practice.
extension_ideas: Sort by color while transferring
Use smaller items for challenge
Time yourself — how fast can you transfer them all?

title: Sandpaper Letter — m
description: Introduction to the sandpaper letter 'm'. Multi-sensory learning of the letter shape and its sound /m/.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'm'.
2. Trace with two fingers while saying '/m/' (humming sound).
3. Repeat 3 times.
4. Child traces while saying the sound.
5. Three-period lesson: naming, recognition, recall.
6. Review: show both 's' and 'm'. 'Which one says /m/? Which says /s/?'

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we get to learn a brand new letter. It makes a special sound, and we're going to learn all about it!

slides.setup_instructions: Place sandpaper letter 'm' on the tray. Keep 's' nearby for the review portion.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special bumpy letter 'm' for this. We also have a letter 's' to help us practice later. We can put the 'm' on a tray, like a little bed for our letter.

slides.text: 'Today we have a new sound!' Trace 'm' with two fingers: 'mmm.' Repeat 3 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, watch me first! We're going to use two fingers to trace the letter 'm' like this. As we trace, we make a humming sound: "mmm." Let's do it together three times!

slides.text: Guide the child's hand: 'Now you trace it. Say mmm as you trace.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to feel the bumpy letter! Use your two fingers to trace the 'm' just like we did. As you trace, remember to make the "mmm" sound. You can do it!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This says /m/.' 'Show me /m/.' 'What sound does this make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a little game to help us remember! I'll show you the letter and tell you its sound, then you show me. Then, I'll ask you what sound it makes.

slides.text: Review: Place 's' and 'm' side by side. 'Which one says /s/?' 'Which one says /m/?' Scramble and repeat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have our letters 's' and 'm' right next to each other. Can you show me which one makes the "mmm" sound? And which one makes the "sss" sound? Let's try it a few times!

slides.prompt: Trace both letters 3 times each. Try writing /m/ in the sand tray!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice tracing both letters again, three times each. If you have the sand tray, you can even try drawing the letter 'm' in the soft sand! It's like drawing with your finger.

slides.text: 'You know two letters now — /s/ and /m/!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish /s/ and /m/ sandpaper letters?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job! You learned the letter 'm' and its "mmm" sound. You can even tell it apart from the letter 's' now. You're such a super learner!

parent_notes: We introduce letters in a specific order based on frequency and ease of writing/sounding. Consonants and vowels are typically on different colored backgrounds (pink for consonants, blue for vowels in many sets). Reviewing previously learned letters each time builds long-term memory. Keep sessions short and joyful — stop before the child loses interest.

title: Number Rods — Extension to 7
description: Extending the number rod work to include rods 6 and 7. The child counts longer sequences and compares quantities.
instructions:
1. Review rods 1-5 briefly.
2. Introduce rod 6. Count each segment together: 'One, two, three, four, five, six.'
3. Introduce rod 7. Count together.
4. Build the full stair (1-7).
5. Compare: 'Which is longer, 5 or 7? How many more does 7 have?'
6. Three-period lesson for 6 and 7.

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to play a fun math game with special blocks called Number Rods. Today, we're going to learn about even bigger ones, number six and number seven!

slides.setup_instructions: Have all rods 1-7 available. Begin with a quick review of 1-5.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful blocks! These are our Number Rods, and we need them all to build a tall tower. We also have a big mat to put them on, so they don't roll away.

slides.text: Review: Build the stair 1-5 together. Count each rod to refresh.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build our tower with the blocks we already know! We'll put them in order from shortest to longest and count them all together, just like we practiced before.

slides.text: Introduce rod 6: 'Here's a new rod! Let's count.' Touch each segment: 'One, two, three, four, five, six!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this new red block? This is rod number six! Let's count the little squares on it together: one, two, three, four, five, six! You did it!

slides.text: Introduce rod 7. Count together. Place both new rods in the stair.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have another new block, this one is white. Let's count this one too, all the way to seven! Then we'll put our new blocks with the others to make our tower even taller.

slides.prompt: Build the stair from 1 to 7! Then play: 'Show me six!' 'Which rod has seven?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to build the whole tower from one all the way to seven! After you build it, you can point to the block that shows six or the block that shows seven when I ask.

slides.text: Return rods carefully. 'You can count all the way to seven!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count and order rods 1-7?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building the tower all the way to seven! You can count so many numbers now. Remember how tall the seven block was? That was amazing counting!

parent_notes: We extend gradually: 1-5 first, then 6-7, then 8-10 next week. This respects the child's working memory. Comparing rods builds the foundation for subtraction. 'How many more does 7 have than 5?' is an early subtraction concept, though we don't name it as such yet.

title: Land and Water Forms — Island and Lake
description: Introduction to the first pair of opposite land and water forms: island and lake. The child creates models and learns the definitions.
instructions:
1. Show the land/water form trays for island and lake.
2. Pour water into each. 'An island is land surrounded by water. A lake is water surrounded by land.'
3. Let the child pour water and observe.
4. Make an island and a lake with clay in a baking dish.
5. Draw an island and a lake.
6. 'They are opposites!'

slides.heading: Land and Water Forms
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the title! We're going to learn about land and water today, and some special shapes called islands and lakes. It's going to be so much fun exploring with you!

items: Island and lake form trays (or DIY with clay and baking dishes)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the trays on a towel. Have water and drawing materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special things ready for our adventure! We need those bumpy trays, a pitcher with some water, and some blue crayon and paper. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: Show the island tray: 'This is an island. An island is land surrounded by water.' Pour water around it.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this tray? It has some land in the middle, right? We're going to pour water all around it, and that makes it an island! An island is just land with water all around it, like a little piece of land in the big ocean.

slides.text: Show the lake tray: 'This is a lake. A lake is water surrounded by land.' Pour water into it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at this other tray! This one has a big space in the middle, and we're going to fill it with water. This is a lake, and a lake is like a big puddle of water with land all around it.

slides.text: 'Island and lake are opposites! An island has land in the middle. A lake has water in the middle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, an island has land in the middle and water all around, and a lake has water in the middle and land all around! They are like opposites, aren't they? One has land in the middle, and the other has water in the middle!

slides.prompt: Draw an island: color water (blue) around a piece of land. Draw a lake: color water (blue) in the middle of land.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! We're going to draw a picture. First, let's draw an island by coloring the water blue all around some land. Then, let's draw a lake by coloring the water blue in the middle, with land all around it.

slides.text: 'You learned two land and water forms today — island and lake!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define and distinguish island and lake?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! We learned all about islands and lakes today! You are so good at understanding new things, and you're going to be a super geography explorer!

parent_notes: Montessori always presents land and water forms in pairs of opposites: island/lake, peninsula/gulf, isthmus/strait, etc. This helps the child understand the relationship between land and water. You can make DIY trays using air-dry clay in shallow baking dishes — mold the land form and let it dry, then add water for the lesson.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
