title: Bell Introduction — Loud and Soft
description: Introduction to the Montessori bells concept through exploring loud and soft sounds. The child experiments with volume using simple instruments.
instructions:
1. Gather simple instruments: a bell, a drum or pot, a shaker.
2. Demonstrate loud sounds and soft sounds.
3. 'This is LOUD.' (strike drum hard) 'This is soft.' (tap gently)
4. Let the child experiment with each instrument.
5. Play 'Loud or Soft': you play, the child identifies.
6. Take turns: child plays, parent identifies.

slides.heading: Music Exploration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we get to play with music and learn about how sounds can be big and small. We're going to discover all about loud sounds and soft sounds, like when a little mouse squeaks or a big lion roars!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange instruments on a table or mat. Ensure a quiet environment so sounds are clear.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our music makers ready! See this shiny bell? We can make it sing. And look, a drum (or maybe a pot and spoon!) – that can make a BIG sound! And this is a shaker, it makes a fun sound too. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can play.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to explore sounds! Listen carefully.' Ring the bell softly, then loudly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's listen closely together! First, I'm going to make a sound with our little bell. Shhh... listen. Now, I'm going to make it sing again, but super soft this time, like a little whisper. Can you hear the difference?

slides.text: 'That was SOFT.' (whisper) Ring again gently. 'That was LOUD!' (speak normally) Ring hard.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try our drum! Listen... *tap, tap, tap*. That was a soft sound, wasn't it? Now watch this! *BANG!* That was a LOUD sound! We're going to use our voices to say "soft" and "loud" too, like a little whisper and a big voice.

slides.text: Let the child try each instrument. 'Can you make a soft sound? Now a loud sound?'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to be the music maker! Pick up your bell, or the drum, or the shaker. Can you make a very, very soft sound? Now, can you make a really loud sound? You can try making soft and loud sounds with all of them!

slides.prompt: Play 'Loud or Soft': close your eyes and listen. Is the sound loud or soft? Take turns!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun game called "Loud or Soft"! Close your eyes tight, and I'll make a sound. When I'm done, tell me if it was loud or soft. Then it will be your turn to make a sound and I'll guess! We'll take turns being the sound maker.

slides.text: 'We learned about loud and soft today. Music is all about how sounds change!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child produce and identify loud versus soft sounds?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about loud and soft sounds today, just like a big roaring bear and a tiny little bird! You were so good at making loud sounds and soft sounds and telling them apart. Music is so much fun when we listen to all the different sounds!

parent_notes: In a Montessori classroom, the bells are a specialized material for teaching pitch discrimination. At home, we begin with simpler concepts: loud/soft (dynamics). Household items work perfectly. This lays groundwork for later music appreciation. Keep the atmosphere calm and listening-focused, even when making loud sounds — it's about conscious control of sound.
household_substitutes: Pots, pans, wooden spoons for rhythm
preparation_steps: Gather sound-making objects. Choose a space where noise is okay.
control_of_error: Can the child repeat a rhythm pattern? Can they keep a steady beat?
extension_ideas: Create a simple song together
Clap rhythm patterns for each other to copy
Listen to different genres and compare

title: Brown Stair — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Brown Stair (Broad Stair). The child arranges the prisms from thickest to thinnest, developing visual discrimination of width.
instructions:
1. Carry each prism to the mat one at a time.
2. Scatter the prisms on the mat.
3. Find the thickest prism. Place it at the left.
4. Find the next thickest. Place it next to the first.
5. Continue until all 10 prisms form a stair.
6. Run fingers along the stair to feel the graduation.

slides.heading: The Brown Stair
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to learn about something called the Brown Stair. It's all about how things can go from super big and chunky to skinny and thin.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the mat on the floor. Carry prisms one at a time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these blocks! These are our Brown Stair blocks, and they are all different widths, like some are fat and some are skinny. We also need this big mat to play on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you get them ready?

slides.text: Carry the thickest prism first. Wrap both hands around it. 'Feel how thick this one is!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pick up the very, very thickest block first. Give it a big hug with both your hands! Feel how wide it is? This is the start of our stair.

slides.text: Scatter all prisms on the mat. 'Now let's find the thickest one and build a stair.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put all the blocks on the mat. We're going to use our eyes to find the thickest one and then the next thickest, and put them all in a line.

slides.text: Place the thickest at the left. Find the next thickest. Place it beside the first. Continue.
slides.mascot_explanation: We found the thickest block, and now we need to find the one that's just a little bit skinnier to go next to it. We'll keep finding the next skinnier one until we have a whole line of blocks that looks like a stair!

slides.text: When complete, run your hand along the top — feel the stair stepping down from thick to thin.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's gently run our fingers along the top of all the blocks. Can you feel how it goes down, down, down from the thickest side to the thinnest side? It’s like a little slide for your fingers!

slides.prompt: Mix them up and build the stair again! Can you do it by yourself this time?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's mix all the blocks up again! Now, try to build the stair all by yourself this time. You can do it! It's like a fun puzzle.

slides.text: Carry each prism back to the shelf. 'You built the Brown Stair!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child arrange prisms from thickest to thinnest?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You built the Brown Stair all by yourself! You are so good at putting things from thick to thin. Let's carefully put all the blocks back where they belong.

parent_notes: The Brown Stair isolates the concept of WIDTH (or thickness). While the Pink Tower changes in 3 dimensions, the Brown Stair changes in only 2 (width and height remain equal while length stays constant). This precision teaches the child to discriminate a single attribute. If you don't have the official material, you can use blocks or boxes of graduated widths.

title: Metal Insets — Introduction (Circle)
description: Introduction to the metal insets using the circle. The child traces the frame and inset to develop pencil control in preparation for writing.
instructions:
1. Select the circle metal inset and its frame.
2. Place the frame on the paper. Hold firmly. Trace the inside of the frame with a colored pencil.
3. Remove the frame. Place the inset inside the traced shape. Trace around the inset with a different color.
4. Show the child: the two lines should overlap.
5. Fill in the shape with parallel lines using a third color.
6. Let the child practice independently.

slides.heading: Metal Insets
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about something super special today called "Metal Insets." This one is a circle, and it will help our hands get strong and ready for writing our names!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the frame and inset on a tray with paper and pencils. Choose 3 different colors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special tools ready for our fun art project! We have a round metal shape, a paper, and three colorful pencils. Make sure you have your tray, too, so we can keep everything tidy. Ask your grown-up to help you gather them all!

slides.text: Place the metal frame on the paper. Hold it firmly with one hand. 'We're going to trace inside the frame.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put the metal circle frame right on top of our paper. Hold it down nice and still with your hand so it doesn't wiggle. We're going to trace the inside of this shape, just like we're coloring a special path!

slides.text: With the first color, trace slowly around the inside of the frame. Lift the frame — you drew a circle!
slides.mascot_explanation: Pick one of your colorful pencils, and let's trace slowly inside the frame we just held. Go all the way around, following the edge. When you lift the frame, ta-da! You made a perfect circle all by yourself!

slides.text: Now place the inset inside the traced circle. With a second color, trace around the inset.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we take the other round metal piece and put it right inside the circle we just drew. Grab a different color pencil this time and trace around this inside piece. Look, we have two circles now, one inside the other!

slides.text: With a third color, fill the shape with parallel lines — left to right, close together, staying inside the lines.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our last color, we're going to fill up the space between the two circles. Let's draw straight lines, going side to side, like little train tracks, and try to stay inside the lines. We're making a beautiful pattern!

slides.prompt: Make your own metal inset design! Trace, outline, and fill with parallel lines.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make your very own metal inset picture! You get to trace the shapes and fill them in with all your beautiful colors. You have lots of time to make it super special!

slides.text: 'Beautiful work! Your hand is getting ready for writing.' Display the design.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the frame and attempt to fill with parallel lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job making your circle design! See how neat and tidy your lines are? You are doing such a great job getting your hands ready for writing, just like a big kid!

parent_notes: Metal insets are Montessori's indirect preparation for handwriting. The child practices the precise pencil control needed for letter formation without writing actual letters. The three steps (trace frame, trace inset, fill with lines) develop the skills of grip, pressure, and controlled movement. If you don't have metal insets, use stencils or cookie cutters as templates.

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 4, 5 and Review
description: Introduction of sandpaper numerals 4 and 5, followed by a review of all numerals 1-5.
instructions:
1. Review sandpaper numerals 1, 2, 3 quickly.
2. Introduce numeral 4. Trace while saying 'four.' Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce numeral 5. Trace while saying 'five.' Three-period lesson.
4. Lay out all 5 numerals. Random recall: 'Show me 3.' 'What is this?'
5. Match all 5 numerals to number rods.
6. Let the child trace and match independently.

slides.heading: Sandpaper Numerals
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to learn about special numbers called "sandpaper numerals" today. We'll meet two new friends, the numbers 4 and 5, and say hello again to the numbers we already know!

slides.setup_instructions: Have numerals 1-3 ready for quick review. Keep 4 and 5 face-down for introduction.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these goodies we need for our learning adventure! We have bumpy numbers made of sandpaper that we'll touch, and special sticks called number rods that show how many. We also have a tray to keep everything neat, like a tidy little table for our numbers. Ask your grown-up to help you find these for our game!

slides.text: Quick review: show 1, 2, 3 one at a time. 'What sound does this make?' (number name)
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's quickly say hello to our number friends we already know! Here's one, here's two, and here's three! Can you remember their names? We're just doing a super fast hello before we meet some new pals.

slides.text: Introduce 4: trace with two fingers, say 'four.' Child traces and repeats. Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet a brand new number friend! This is the number four. Feel how bumpy it is? Let's trace it with our fingers, like we're drawing in soft sand. Say it with me: "four"! It's like counting four little toys!

slides.text: Introduce 5: trace and say 'five.' Child traces. Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here comes another new number friend, the number five! Feel its bumpy shape with your fingers, just like we did with four. Let's trace it together and say its name nice and clear: "five"! It's like counting all your fingers on one hand!

slides.text: All 5 numerals on the table. Shuffle. 'Show me four!' 'What number is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, all our number friends are here now, from one all the way to five! Let's mix them up a little. Can you point to the number four when I ask? Or maybe you can tell me what number this is! It's like a fun guessing game with our new number pals.

slides.prompt: Match each numeral to its number rod. Line them up: numeral card next to its rod.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a matching game! We have our bumpy numbers and our number sticks. Can you find the number stick that has the same amount as the number four? Let's put them right next to each other, like they're best friends! You're doing so great matching them up!

slides.text: 'You know all the numerals from 1 to 5! Great work this week!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recognize, name, and match numerals 1-5?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You learned all about the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5! You can trace them, say their names, and even match them to their friends. You are such a super learner, and you did a fantastic job exploring numbers today!

parent_notes: By the end of week 1, your child should be comfortable with numerals 1-5 and number rods 1-7. The matching exercise (placing numeral cards next to rods) connects the abstract symbol to the concrete quantity — this is fundamental to mathematical thinking. Review frequently throughout the week, making it feel like a fun game rather than a test.

title: Living and Non-Living — Sorting
description: Introduction to the concept of living and non-living things. The child sorts objects and pictures into two categories.
instructions:
1. Gather items from the nature walk and some household objects.
2. Introduce the concept: 'Some things are alive — they grow, breathe, and need food and water. Some things are not alive.'
3. Hold up a leaf: 'Is this living or non-living? It came from a living tree!'
4. Hold up a rock: 'This is non-living. It doesn't grow or eat.'
5. Sort all items into two groups.
6. Discuss tricky items (a wooden spoon: non-living, but it came from a living tree).

slides.heading: Living and Non-Living
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to learn about all the amazing things around us and sort them into two special groups: things that are alive and things that are not alive. It's going to be so much fun exploring our world together!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up two mats with labels. Gather 8-10 items to sort.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get ready for our sorting game! We need some treasures from our nature walk, like leaves or sticks, and some things from around the house too. We also need two special mats, one for "living" things and one for "non-living" things, with their names on them. Can you help ask a grown-up to find all these things for us?

slides.text: 'Everything in our world is either LIVING or NON-LIVING. Living things grow, breathe, eat, and drink water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what does it mean for something to be "living"? It means it can grow big and strong, it needs to breathe air, and it needs yummy food and water to keep going, just like you! Everything around us is either a living thing that does these things, or a non-living thing that doesn't.

slides.text: Hold up a leaf: 'This came from a tree. Trees are living! They grow and need water.' Place on 'Living' mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this pretty leaf? It came from a big, tall tree! Trees are living things because they grow and need water to live, so this leaf goes in our "living" group. It's like a little part of something that's alive!

slides.text: Hold up a rock: 'Does a rock grow? Does it eat? No! Rocks are non-living.' Place on 'Non-Living' mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, look at this smooth rock. Does a rock grow bigger all by itself? Nope! Does it need to eat food or drink water? No way! Rocks don't do those things, so they are "non-living." We'll put this rock in the non-living pile.

slides.prompt: Sort all the items! Pick up each one and decide: living or non-living? Place it on the right mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time for the best part – we get to sort everything ourselves! Pick up each thing we found, and let's think together: does it grow and need food, or is it like the rock? Then we'll put it on the right mat, living or non-living. You can do it!

slides.text: Review: point to each sorted item. 'Why is this living? Why is this non-living?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly sort 6 out of 8 items?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job sorting! Let's look at all the things we put in the "living" pile and talk about why they are alive. And look at our "non-living" pile too! You are so good at figuring out what's living and what's not – that was amazing work!

parent_notes: This is the child's first classification in science. Keep it simple: living things grow, eat, breathe, and reproduce. Dead things (like a dried leaf) can be discussed as 'it WAS living.' Some items are intentionally tricky — a wooden table is non-living but came from a living tree. These conversations build critical thinking. Don't expect perfection; the discussion is the learning.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?

title: Seasonal Art — Fall Leaf Rubbing
description: Creating leaf rubbings using real leaves and crayons. The child discovers the vein patterns and textures of different leaves.
instructions:
1. Collect 3-5 different leaves (various shapes and sizes).
2. Place a leaf vein-side up under a piece of paper.
3. Hold the paper still with one hand.
4. Rub the side of a crayon over the paper — the leaf pattern appears!
5. Try different leaves and colors.
6. Talk about the vein patterns you see.
materials_needed: Tape (optional, to hold leaves in place)

slides.heading: Seasonal Art
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun art project we're going to do! It's called "Seasonal Art," and we're going to make beautiful pictures using leaves from the fall. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Collect leaves beforehand. Remove crayon wrappers so the side can be used for rubbing.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our leaf pictures, we need a few special things. We need some pretty leaves, some paper to draw on, and some crayons. Make sure the paper from the crayons is all off so we can use the side to make our art! Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things.

slides.text: Place a leaf on the table with the vein side UP. Lay paper on top. (Tape corners if needed.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our leaf ready! We need to put a leaf on the table, but it's important to put it on the side that has all the bumpy lines, called veins, pointing up. Then, we put our paper right on top of the leaf.

slides.text: Hold the paper still. Rub the side of the crayon gently back and forth over the leaf area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we need to hold the paper down with one hand so it doesn't move. With your other hand, take a crayon and gently rub the side of it back and forth over the paper, right where the leaf is.

slides.text: 'Look! The leaf is appearing! Can you see the veins?' Try another leaf with a different color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look what happened! The leaf's pattern is showing up on the paper! Can you see those bumpy lines, the veins? Let's try using a different color crayon and maybe even a different leaf to see what else we can make.

slides.prompt: Make rubbings of all your leaves. Try using different colors! Which leaf has the most interesting pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part! Let's make rubbings of all the different leaves we have. Try using all sorts of colors for your crayons! We can see which leaf makes the prettiest pattern.

slides.text: Label each leaf rubbing if the child knows the leaf names. Display your leaf art!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child produce a recognizable leaf rubbing?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job making leaf rubbings! They look amazing! If you know the names of the leaves, we can write them on the pictures. Then we can hang up your beautiful fall art for everyone to see!

parent_notes: Leaf rubbings combine art with botany — the child sees the structure of the leaf (veins, edges) through the art process. This connects to future botany lessons about leaf parts. Use flat, fresh leaves for the best results. Adjust this for your current season — spring leaves, summer leaves, or fall colored leaves all work beautifully. This is a wonderful independent activity once shown.
household_substitutes: Cup of water and paper towels
preparation_steps: Cover the work surface. Set out materials in order of use. Demonstrate technique first.
control_of_error: Art is self-expressive — focus on the process, not the product.
extension_ideas: Display the artwork proudly
Try the same subject with a different medium
Look at famous artwork for inspiration
